description: Test dataset for evaluating BM25+ handling of rare terms

documents.title: Common Programming Languages
documents.body: Python, JavaScript, and Java are among the most popular programming languages used today. They are widely adopted in various domains.

documents.title: Rare Programming Languages
documents.body: Haskell, OCaml, and Erlang are functional programming languages with unique features. Prolog is a logic programming language. APL uses special symbols for operations.
documents.description: Overview of less common programming languages.

documents.title: Esoteric Programming Languages
documents.body: Brainfuck is a minimalist esoteric language. Whitespace uses only whitespace characters. INTERCAL was designed to be unlike any other language. Malbolge is deliberately difficult to use.
documents.description: Overview of extremely rare and unusual programming languages.

documents.title: Domain-Specific Languages
documents.body: SQL is used for database queries. R is specialized for statistics. MATLAB is used for mathematical computations. Verilog is used for hardware description.

documents.title: Ancient Programming Languages
documents.body: FORTRAN was developed in the 1950s. COBOL was designed for business use. LISP introduced many important concepts. ALGOL influenced many subsequent languages.
documents.description: Historical programming languages that shaped computing.

queries.description: BM25+ should rank rt3 higher than BM25 would, as these are extremely rare terms
BM25+ should rank rt2 higher than BM25 would, as these are rare terms
BM25+ and BM25 should rank rt1 similarly, as these are common terms
BM25+ should rank rt5 higher than BM25 would, as these are relatively rare terms
BM25+ should rank rt4 higher than BM25 would, as these are domain-specific terms

notes: The key difference between BM25 and BM25+ should be in the score values, not necessarily in the ranking order. BM25+ should assign higher scores to documents containing rare terms compared to BM25.
